all_data.speaker: Linnea Freeman
all_data.transcript: of the enteric nervous system and how this intersects with the central nervous system and the microbiome.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The utterance explains the relationship between the enteric nervous system, the central nervous system, and the microbiome, providing context for the discussion.

all_data.speaker: Noah Palm
all_data.transcript: Zoom into this. Microbes also evolved to use many of those same signals for communication purposes or competition or whatever. Microbes invented all of the neurotransmitters, right? That's actually how it worked. It's not that they're neurotransmitters and the microbes figured out how to make them. The microbes invented dopamine, epinephrine, norepinephrine. It's because they're simple biotransformations of amino acids, simple modifications of amino acids and thus they're evolutionarily very, very useful. And so, I guess, to me, the bigger challenge that the system faces to your point actually that you were talking about say for using epinephrine or norepinephrine to regulate lymphoid structures is the fact that when you go to the gut, you have all these microbes basically screaming at you all the time with these. And if you choose then to use those signals to build those systems, the microbes are more an interloper than anything else. And so I think, I guess to start on kind of the last question, to me, one of the challenges of the organizations of the structures is to have compartmentalization in a way where you don't have signals from, you know, the metaorganism side of things that you don't have control over genomically, evolutionarily, messing with your own evolution of of tissue structures or cellular communication within the host. But this is my anyway, this is my biased point of view. I'll stop because I've thought a lot about certain aspects of this. I don't know Sarkis if you have thoughts if that's consistent with your thinking.
all_data.screenshare_content: A slide titled "Neuroinflammation" with session number 2.2 & 2.3 is displayed. The slide contains three bullet points: Recent work has shown between serine/choline while understanding the intertangled role of neurons and immune cells, Is there crosstalk between neuronal synthesized and entire synthesized which is fine from cradle/gut to mature cells and entire metaorganism, and How do we understand the organization, structures, and boundaries of the nervous system and the microbiome.

annotations.present new idea: Noah Palm introduces the idea that microbes, not neurotransmitters, were the original inventors of dopamine, epinephrine, and norepinephrine.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Noah Palm builds on the idea of microbial communication by explaining that these signals pose a challenge to the host's regulation of lymphoid structures.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Noah Palm supports his claim about microbial invention of neurotransmitters by explaining that they are simple biotransformations of amino acids, making them evolutionarily useful.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: Noah Palm explains the challenge of using certain signals for regulation due to the constant presence of microbes in the gut.
annotations.encourage participation: Noah Palm invites Sarkis to share his thoughts on the topic.

So I think we have a lot of um gaps still in knowledge before we can really identify that.
